div.head:
Embleme 23. Of the Secrets of Nature.
When Pallas was borne, and Sol lay with Venus, it rained gold
at Rhodes.

lg.l: This prodigy seems more than strange to us,
Yet GræceGreece for truth hath it affirmed thus:
The clouds did twice at Rhodes their joy declare,
Show'ringShowering downe gold through the receding aire;
When Sol to Venus payd the dues of love,
And Pallas Sprung out of the braine of Jove.

div.head: Discourse 23.
div.ab:
It would be madnessemadness to affirme that gold ever rained upon the earth, except
it was allegorically understood: for there are noe golden rivers, or Mynes of-
gold veins in the clouds, that it could be sayd to be there generated, nor is gold of
soe little weight, as to be thought to be attracted with vapours: but a Trope ad
mittsadmits and excusethexcuses all these things; for soe truely as Pallas actually sprung
from Jupiters brain, and Sol coḿittedcommitted adultery with Venus, soe truely allso
fell golden raine; not as if wee doubt both those things to have happened,-
but to take away the vulgar and literall sense from things allegorically
spoken: for if wee follow the bare words of this Embleme, there is nothing
more absurd than them, if the meaning, nothing more true. Now Rhodes-
is an Island, first called Ophinsa by reason of the multitude of Serpents,-
